(71) Furthermore, one who is good at discernment, even if the country is vast and well-endowed, knows its suffering and distress and abandons it to leave.

I once heard that when the World-Honored One was a bodhisattva in the past, he was a great king. To the poor and destitute who came to beg, he gave everything. For those in suffering and distress, he was able to provide protection. In order to benefit all sentient beings, he was wise, intelligent, and also held the position of king.
At that time, the king of a neighboring country brought his troops and was about to come to engage in battle. The bodhisattva king had this thought:

Attached to the five desires and pleasures, one cannot tame the mind. The six sense faculties are difficult to satisfy, and there are many requisites. Moreover, they need to be managed and protected. For the sake of these requisites, disputes arise. I wish to abandon this matter and should not quarrel. I should further cultivate the supreme Dharma that follows the body.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
When examining what is good, the wise should discern,
If one does not contemplate before acting, regret will be of no avail afterwards.
Examining right and wrong, one will certainly know where they lie.
He further spoke a verse, saying:
Desire is like grasping a torch, and also like a mass of flesh,
If one clings to desire, one will surely be injured, and harm will extend to both this and future lives.
The wise should quickly leave behind the country, possessions, and so forth,
Such possessions and so forth, will eventually be abandoned,
It is better to endure the various sufferings now, and not wish for the long-lasting suffering in the future,
One is able to crush and subdue them, and clearly realize the fruits in the present,
With a good reputation and praise, later one will suffer harm and injury.
Although one knows one has the ability, one should wish to protect them,
If one does not protect them, later one will surely injure one's body.
Having had this thought, he fled and entered the forest. There was an old brahmin who had lost his way and came to the forest. The Bodhisattva asked him:
Why have you come to this forest?
The brahmin said:
I want to see the king.
The Bodhisattva asked:
Why do you want to see the king?
The brahmin said:
I am now poor and in debt. I heard that the king is generous, so I came to beg in order to repay my debts.
Far from the suffering of poverty, I have nowhere else to turn. I only hope for the king's grace to save me.
The Bodhisattva said:
You should all return. There is no king here. To whom should you pay homage?
When the brahmin heard these words, he fainted and fell to the ground.
At that time, the Bodhisattva, having seen this, deeply felt pity. Having had this thought, he then spoke a verse, saying:
I have given up what is difficult to abandon for the sake of protecting others,
Having given up now, what else can I give?
For this person, I will now give up my own life.
Having spoken this verse, he immediately helped the brahmin up and said to him:
Do not be afraid!
I will make you obtain wealth and profit.
When the brahmin heard these words, he was overjoyed. The Bodhisattva immediately made a rope out of grass. After making the rope, he gave it to the brahmin:
I am the one who gives everything.
And he spoke this verse:
The king has not yet obtained me, and his mind will never be at ease.
You should use this rope to bind my elbows,
And take me to the king, causing the king to be delighted.
He will give you precious treasures, gold, silver, and various goods.
You can obtain great wealth, and the king will be delighted.
Those who are born will certainly die, and life will eventually come to an end.
In order to save from danger and calamity, even if one loses one's life,
The wise die for this, and it is called an ornament.
At that time, the brÄhman, having heard these words, was greatly delighted. He immediately bound the Bodhisattva with a rope and took him to the king.
When the king saw him, he said to the brÄhman in verse:
Who is this person?
His majestic radiance is extremely brilliant, like the sun illuminating the world,
His facial features are extremely dignified, and no one who sees him is not delighted.
One with such blessings and virtues should be the lord of the great earth,
Yet today he is bound and captured, and his suffering and calamity are like this?
Sitting on my lion throne, I am extremely ashamed,
He should be the one to take the throne, not me.
I am not disciplined, so I should not sit on this seat.
Then the brahmin, having heard these verses, said to the great king:
This is your enemy.
The king asked the brahmin:
Who bound this man?
The brahmin said:
This was indeed bound by me.
The king said:
This man should not be bound by you. You are lying.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
He is like a great wild elephant, with extremely strong bodily strength.
You are now weak in body and lack the strength of soldiers and horses.
How can you bind him?
This is unbelievable.
You should speak the truth, do not speak falsely.
Then the brahmin fully explained the above matter and spoke a verse, saying:
Seeing that I have lost my hope, that person will then bind himself,
He will bind himself with compassion, wishing to save and deliver me.
Such a good man, his fame spreads in the ten directions,
Just like a burning torch, illuminating everything.
The unwholesome people are foolish, they will extinguish him without remainder,
When the torch is blazing, it can extinguish him without leaving anything behind.
At that time, the great king, having heard these words, immediately got up in surprise and said with his palms joined:
Excellent, excellent!
A true good man!
You do such things to save others.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
The one called the great king is named RÄja,
Benefiting the world, therefore called RÄja.
You should now be the king, protecting and upholding the great earth,
I only wish that you will now listen to me, and repent of all my faults.
I am truly a foolish child, fickle and ignorant,
You may return to be king, I will abandon this country and leave.
You are able to cause all sentient beings to attain peace and happiness,
If other people become king, they will oppress the world.
He then established that king and returned to his abode.
Next, one should make pure meritorious deeds and set up offerings. Therefore, one should diligently cultivate meritorious deeds.

I once heard that in the country of Shi Shi, there was a king named Wu Yue Qian. The people of the whole country held a Buddhist assembly together. A woman peeked at the World-Honored One through a window.
At that time, the king saw that the woman was upright and handsome, so he untied his pearl necklace and sent a courtier to give it to the woman.
At that time, the king's attendants immediately said to the king:
That woman is the wife of a man in the country. If the king loves her, he can just go and fetch her. Why bother with a pearl?
People might find it strange and laugh.
When the king heard these words, he covered his ears with his hands and said, Alas! How terrible!
How can such words be heard by me?
He then spoke a verse, saying:
If I make this oath and say that I have a different mind,
May I become greatly evil. I do not give the pearl to that woman
Because I want to hear what she has to say.
Karma is the sovereign lord, the most excellent karma is said to be
This is not created by a creator, but only made by karma.
The mind acts as the creator, and good karma is praised by the Buddha.
Such a wonderful form has no other creator but me.
It is only created by good karma. I should respect good karma.
I should avoid evil karma.
The fruits and retributions are now manifest. I used a string of pearls
Adorned with various treasures, with a cintamani hanging from my forehead,
The string of pearls as white as snow. I am due to my past merits,
Not attached to sensual desires. If I know good and evil karma,
How can I still be attached to form?
Even from afar I do not look, let alone be attached.
Not greedy for what is contrary to the Dharma, I would rather enter a fire pit,
Not engage in deceitful and perverse acts.
If I have attachment, in this life or the next, I will suffer immeasurable pain.

Furthermore, if there is good karma, due to the power of the natural force one will receive good karmic retribution. Even if there is the power of the king's partisans, it is not as good as the good retribution obtained by the power of karma. Therefore, one should cultivate good karma.
I once heard that King Ujja, while taking a nap during the day, had two inner officials, one in front of his head and one at his feet, holding fans and whisks, discussing together:
Whom does the king think of now? For what matter?
One claimed it was due to his own karmic power, while the other claimed it was due to the king's power, and for this reason he served the king.
At that time, the two of them often heard the Dharma and understood discussions, so they spoke in verse:
Just as an ox leads the way across the water, the followers also go straight.
When the king establishes the right Dharma, the followers are also like this.
At that time, because the two of them were competing in reasoning, their voices gradually rose. One said:
I live by relying on the king.
The second one said:
I rely on the power of karma.
The king heard this voice and immediately woke up from his sleep, and asked:
Why are you speaking so loudly?

The king heard that the two men were arguing about principles, and although he clearly knew that they had not yet eliminated the view of self, he was displeased that they were siding with each other. He then spoke a verse to the one who claimed the power of karma:
Relying on my country to live, you claim it is the power of karma,
I will now test you to see whose power it is.
Having spoken this verse, he went to the queen's place and said to the queen:
Now I will send someone to come to your side, you should adorn yourself like the queen of Indra.
She replied:
I will follow the king's instructions!
Then the king gave grape juice to the one who relied on the king for life and sent it to the queen.
After sending it, he thought like this:
The one who claims the power of karma should now repent for speaking such words.
Having had this thought for not long, the one with the power of karma put on nice clothes and came to the king's side.
The king, upon seeing this, was greatly astonished and immediately spoke a verse, saying:
Have I made a mistake myself and given him the remaining juice?
Or is this the power of his karma, forcefully taking this away?
Or perhaps we are close friends, and he has taken it to give to him?
Or perhaps the queen is angry and has taken this to give to him?
Or perhaps I am confused and have given it to him?
Or perhaps he has deceived me and caused me to be confused?
Having spoken this verse, he asked the man, saying:
Speak the truth to me. You rely on the power of karma, so I will not send you away. How did you obtain this?
The man said to the king:
I obtained it through the power of karma.
He then explained the situation in detail to the king, saying:
After this man was sent on an errand and left the gate, he suddenly sneezed. He then gave me this juice to deliver to the queen, and I obtained these clothes.
Upon hearing this, the king spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½Karmic retribution is like a shadow or echo,
And also like that adornment.
What they say is the power of one's own karma, this speech is not false.
Because of the power of listening to the Dharma, speech accords with principle,
What they call the power of karma, this speech certainly has verification.
I have much that I have lost, they rely on the power of karma to be victorious,
The Buddha says the power of karma is strong, this speech is truly real.
The Buddha is a well-controlled mount, the power of karma is excellent,
Able to destroy the power of the king.
The Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones of the ten directions, also say it is according to the power of karma.
You now rely on the power of karma to adorn your body, cutting off my power.
(74) Furthermore, even if one has enmity with the wise, it can still benefit one. Therefore, even if one has enmity with the wise, one should always be close to them.
I once heard that in the country of MathurÄ there was a brÄhman who was intelligent and wise but did not believe in the Buddha's teachings and did not associate with the bhiká¹£us.
He had a dispute with another brÄhman, and out of anger he went to the monastery and falsely said,

He wanted to make the bhiká¹£us go to his house the next morning and not receive food and drink, causing his bad reputation to spread throughout the world.
Then the bhiká¹£us went to his house in the morning and said to the doorkeeper,
Your master invited us to a meal. You can go and tell him.
Then the doorkeeper went in and told the master,
Now there are bhiká¹£us outside the gate who say that the master invited them, so they came to visit.
When the master heard this, he thought,
For what reason is there such a thing?
He then thought:
That brahmin is my enemy, so he did this on purpose.
Now although it is noon, the city is very large, so I will send someone to buy supplies to offer to the monks.
Having thought this, he immediately sent someone to invite the monks to come to his house to take their seats and set up various foods to make offerings.
After the monks had finished eating, they said to the donor:
You may sit down for a moment. It is the duty of monks to expound the Dharma for donors after eating, even though you may not believe it, this is how it is in the Buddha's teachings.
At that time, the host took a small bed and sat in front of the senior monk.
He expounded the teachings on giving, precepts, and rebirth in the heavens, that desire is impure and the world beyond is blissful, and even expounded the Dharma of the Four Noble Truths.
This brahmin had already planted various wholesome roots in the past, and while sitting there he saw the Four Noble Truths and attained the stage of stream-entry, and spoke a verse, saying:
Alas, the power of foolishness can harm right views,
The foolish do not discriminate, regarding treasures as worthless.
I now gain victory, discriminating and recognizing the Three Jewels,
The true treasure is the Buddha, the Dharma, and the noble Sangha.
I have already seen clearly, gaining the closing of the three evil paths,
The Åšakras, BrahmÄs, and various gods are unable to obtain,
I now fully obtain.
It is called the Brahma Heaven, now I will go towards,
The direction of liberation and immortality.
I have now begun to obtain, the supreme Dharma of a brÄhman.
Today is truly a day of giving, today I have begun to obtain,
The supreme and wonderful Pita Dharma.
Surpassing all the Pitas, I am now truly,
A great field of merit for sacrifices.
I should diligently perform great sacrifices, unable to skillfully discriminate, what can be sacrificed and what cannot be sacrificed?
From today onward, I will make offerings to the Buddha,
the TathÄgata.ğŸ”½To put it briefly, I have gained benefits today,
and obtained the fruit of a human body.
From today onward, I will follow the Buddha's teachings,ğŸ”½and will never again request
the other celestial spirits.
The Dharma I now study, in accordance with the right path,
the Dharma and the Dharma-followers, I will surely attain its fruit.
I now take refuge and pay homage to the one who in past lives detested the faculties,
who once cultivated the Dharma and followed the Dharma, and now attains its beneficial fruit.
By closely following the good and wise advisor, the benefits of the Dharma naturally come about.
If I had not closely followed the disciple of great compassion,
I would have forever fallen into wrong views, and transmigrated through the three evil paths.
If it were not for the brÄhmaá¹‡a who became my enemy,
One should not be intimate with such a holy assembly.
Because of his anger and resentment, he caused me to attain this Dharma.
Outwardly resembling a bad friend, he is actually a good teacher,
His kindness surpasses that of parents and relatives.
Because of this brahmin, the monks came to my house,
Pouring down sweet rain, the sprouts of goodness all grew.
The rain of Dharma is very nourishing, sprinkling the dust of my mind,
Since the dust does not arise, I see the true Dharma.
Therefore, the world says that one can obtain wealth because of an enemy.
Thinking that he has gained great benefits, he immediately accepts the Three Refuges.
To that brahmin, he prepares various delicacies.
(75) Furthermore, if a person sincerely gives with wealth, like obtaining wealth with flowers, knowing this matter, one should give with a sincere mind.
I once heard that in the country of KÄÅ›mÄ«ra, a husband and wife were sleeping together on a grass mat. At dawn, the wife suddenly woke up and had this thought:

In this country, there are countless hundreds of thousands of people who all cultivate merit and make offerings to the saá¹ƒgha. We are poor and have encountered this treasure island, but if we do not take a little treasure to the next life, our suffering will be endless. I now have no merit and my future suffering will be long.
Having thought this, he sighed sadly, and his tears fell on his wife.
At that time, the wife asked her husband:
Why are you so unhappy?
And she spoke a verse, saying:
Why are you so extremely sad?
You sigh again and again, and your tears fall on my arm, as if pouring water on it.
At that time, the husband spoke a verse in reply, saying:
I have not a shred of good that I can take to the next life,
Having contemplated this matter, I therefore lament for myself.
In the world there are excellent fields of merit, but I have no good seeds to plant.
In this life or the next, the suffering of hunger and poverty is difficult to calculate.
Not planting seeds in previous lives, in this world one is extremely poor.
If one does not act now, in the future there will be no fruits.
At that time, when his wife heard these verses, she said to her husband:
You should not worry.
I belong to you. You have control over my body. If you sell my body, you can obtain wealth to fulfill your wishes.
At that time, when the husband heard these words from his wife, he was overjoyed and his face was filled with delight. He said to his wife:
If it were not for you, I would not be able to live.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
My body and your body are like a pair of mandarin ducks.
We should sell our bodies together, obtain wealth, and cultivate merit.
At that time, the couple went to the elder's house and said:
Please lend us gold. If we cannot repay it within a month, the two of us will become your slaves. Within a month, we can make offerings to the assembly of bhiká¹£us.
At that time, the elder immediately gave them gold. Having obtained the gold, they said to each other:
We can make offerings to the assembly of monks in the Liyue Temple.
The wife asked her husband:
On which day should we do it?
He replied:
On the fifteenth day.
She asked again:
Why the fifteenth day?
At that time, the husband answered in verse:
In the world, on the fifteenth day, the heavenly kings such as Kubera
Inspect the world. This is what the Buddha said.
I wish to let humans and gods know, therefore it is the fifteenth day.
At that time, the couple exhausted their efforts in construction until the thirteenth day. The food and supplies were all prepared and sent to the temple. They said to the person in charge:
We only pray, Venerable One!
On the fifteenth day, do not let the monks go out. Please accept our invitation.
The person in charge replied:
Alright.
On the fourteenth day, the couple stayed in the temple and encouraged each other, speaking in verse:
Admonish your own body, be careful not to complain of fatigue,
You now have freedom, you should do your best.
Later, being urged by others, your actions will not be free,
In vain you will endure much hardship, without the slightest benefit.
Having spoken this verse, the couple did not sleep for the entire night, and by dawn, the food and drink were all prepared. The husband said to his wife:
Excellent!
What we have done is accomplished, and our wish is fulfilled.
On this good day, we will sell this body of ours, and for hundreds of thousands of lifetimes, we will always be well-provided for.
At that time, the ruler of a small country prepared food and drink and came to the temple, saying:
I wish for the monks to accept my offerings.
The person in charge said:
We monks have already accepted another invitation. Please find another day.
At that time, the small king earnestly said:
I am now pressed for time due to many affairs. Please accept my invitation.
At that time, the monks remained silent.
At that time, the ruler of the country said to the couple:
I will now strike the gavel myself. I will pay you for the food you have prepared.
At that time, the husband and wife, having heard these words, prostrated themselves in the five ways before the lord of that country and said:

We, husband and wife, are poor and have nothing. We have sold ourselves to prepare offerings. We have finished preparing the offerings and have completed the arrangements. We can only make offerings freely today. If we reach tomorrow, we will be employed by others and will not have freedom. We pray that the king will have pity on us and not take away our day.
Then they spoke a verse, saying:
Husband and wife are like a pair of mandarin ducks. The offerings have already been prepared.
We pray that you will definitely remember us. Tomorrow we will belong to others.
Husband and wife have different employments. There is no more opportunity to cultivate merit.
In this way, we sell ourselves in order to cultivate goodness.
At that time, the king of that country heard this matter in detail and praised it as excellent. He then spoke a verse, saying:
You understand the Buddha's teachings well and clearly recognize cause and effect.
You can easily exchange this illusory body for solid wealth and life.
Do not be afraid, listen to your wishes.
I have pity on you, I will use wealth to repay your price,
You now suffer your body, you will ultimately gain great benefits and happiness.

At that time, after the king said this verse, he allowed the couple to make offerings to the Sangha, and immediately used wealth to repay the couple's price, and also provided the couple with their own livelihood, and they presently received this reward without any lack.
(76) Furthermore, upholding the precepts with utmost sincerity, even to the point of losing one's life, one can attain present karmic rewards.
I once heard that in the city of Nandibal there was an upÄsaka who had two brothers, both upholding the five precepts.

At that time, the younger brother suddenly suffered from a pain in his side and was about to die. The doctor diagnosed him and said that eating the meat of a freshly killed dog and drinking wine would surely cure his illness.
The sick one said:ğŸ”½I have already accepted the five precepts and cannot violate them. If I violate them, I will not be able to be reborn in the heavens.
As for dog meat, it can be bought in the market and eaten. As for drinking alcohol, I would rather give up my life and never break the precepts to drink alcohol.
His older brother saw that his younger brother was in extreme distress and bought alcohol and said to his younger brother:
Give up the precepts, drink alcohol, and cure your illness.
His younger brother said to his older brother:
Although I am gravely ill, I would rather give up my life and never break the precepts to drink this alcohol.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
Alas! At the time of death, break my necklace of precepts,
Adorn my body with precepts, no need for burial goods.
Since a human body is so difficult to obtain, and it is even more difficult to encounter precepts,
I would rather give up hundreds of thousands of lives than destroy the precepts.
For countless hundreds of thousands of eons, one may only encounter the precepts once,
In the world of JambudvÄ«pa, a human body is extremely difficult to obtain,
Although one may obtain a human body, it is even more difficult to encounter the true Dharma.
Sometimes one encounters the Dharma Jewel, but the foolish do not know how to take it.
Those who are good at discerning, this matter is also difficult.
The treasure of precepts has entered my hands, how can you want to take it away?
This is an enemy, not a relative of mine.
When the elder brother heard the verse, he replied to his younger brother:
Because of our kinship, I am not trying to obstruct you.
The younger brother said to his elder brother:
It is not out of kinship, but rather a destruction.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
I want to go to a superior place, but you want to destroy my precepts and cause me to fall.
The harm to me is like this, how can you be called a relative?
I diligently practice the root of precepts, but you want to see it robbed.
Among the five precepts I uphold, the precept against alcohol is the most important.
Now you want to forcefully destroy me, it cannot be called kinship.
The elder brother asked the younger brother:
How can alcohol be the basis of the precepts?
The younger brother then spoke a verse in reply to his elder brother:
If one does not wholeheartedly uphold the precepts,
One will go against great compassion.
I dare not even touch it, therefore I know
That alcohol is the cause of evil paths.
Speaking of the evil retribution of alcohol, only the Buddha can discern it.
Who can fathom it?
The evil conduct of the three karmas, alcohol is the fundamental cause,
And one further falls into evil conduct.
Because of the causes and conditions of alcohol, one eventually destroys the other four precepts,
This is called evil conduct, and is also called the five great gifts,
And is also the five fearlessnesses.
Not drinking closes the evil paths, one can attain a mind of faith and joy,
Remove stinginess and be able to give away wealth.
One can attain immeasurable benefits, I have no other thoughts at all,
But those who wish to violate it?
It is better to give up a thousand lives, than to violate the Buddha's teachings.
It is better to let the body wither, than to drink alcohol.
Even if one violates the precepts and lives for a hundred thousand years,
It is not as good as protecting the precepts and immediately ending one's life.
Even if it can definitely cure me, I still will not drink,
Let alone now, when I am uncertain whether it will cure me or not?
Having made this determination, a great joy arose in my mind.
I immediately attained insight into the truth, and my illness was cured.

(77) Furthermore, if one has faith in the Buddha's words, one regards all external treatises as if spoken by infants, fools, or the insane. Therefore, one should diligently study the Buddha's teachings and treatises.
I once heard that there was a country called ÅšÄkala, and the king was named Rudradatta. That king often went to the temple to listen to the Dharma.
At that time, the Dharma teacher was explaining the faults of alcohol. The king then questioned the Dharma teacher on the high seat, saying:
If giving alcohol to others results in madness and delusion, then those who drink alcohol now should also have many cases of madness and delusion as retribution.
At that time, the Dharma teacher pointed to the non-Buddhists. When the king saw this, he said, Excellent! Excellent!
At that time, the non-Buddhists discussed among themselves, saying:
That Dharma teacher has no knowledge or insight. He is just pointing to empty space. The king, who is the Dharma teacher, also does not understand. He is just empty praise!
He cannot explain and answer this question.
But there are also great and intelligent people in this assembly. Why don't they answer the king's question?
Then they spoke a verse, saying:
The Dharma teacher has sharp eloquence and can skillfully answer this meaning,
But out of compassion for you all, he protects and cherishes it without speaking.
The non-Buddhists said:
The king is the Dharma teacher's patron and speaks on his behalf.
The king said:
What I understand is different.
At that time, the king said to the Dharma teacher:
The meaning you understood earlier can now be explained.
The Dharma teacher replied:
The reason I pointed out the non-Buddhists is that the non-Buddhists each give rise to different views and have inverted minds, and therefore they are called insane people.
He then spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½It is not necessarily those possessed by ghosts
Who are called insane,ğŸ”½Those with the mind of the yaká¹£a of wrong views
Are said to be insane.ğŸ”½The faults of insane and deluded people
Do not understand their affairs,ğŸ”½You have the faults of insanity,
As taught by the omniscient one.ğŸ”½You go against the words of the omniscient one
And follow wrong views,ğŸ”½Clearly seeing the supernatural powers,
You are humiliated by that great sage.ğŸ”½Going beyond his prohibitions,
Insanity has already been formed,ğŸ”½How can you make me explain
The hundreds of thousands of causes of insanity?
Why is it explained in a discriminating manner?
Throwing oneself into a deep pool, jumping into a fire, or falling from a high cliff, abandoning giving and precepts,
Following delusion, perversity, and confusion, not cultivating correct practice,
Confused and falling into fire, selling salt destroys pure conduct.
Drinking and touching the water of the Ganges River, this is called establishing correct practice,
Losing purity and attaining correctness, what is the meaning and purport of this?
Selling meat and gathering various evils, three kinds of spiritual powers transform,
Apart from these three kinds of transformations, there are also other spiritual transformations.
There are only two sets of six dharmas, apart from this there is no separate self,
Currently seeing the spiritual transformations of immortals, further seeing thirteen dharmas.
Thus there are a hundred such crazy events,
Currently seen throwing oneself into deep pools, fire, or falling from a high cliff.
Desiring to be born in the heavens through this, this is merely wrong view,
It is not the cause for being born in the heavens;
Precepts, giving, and a well-disciplined mind are the causes for rebirth in the heavens.
Touching the river removes all evils, selling salt is a great evil,
Touching the river is a great good, what is the meaning of this?
How can it be called good or evil?
Then one falls into the lost Dharma, holding a knife is also lost Dharma,
If one further sells meat, filling thirty-six pounds,
It ruins the Brahmins.
All are called lost Dharma, seeing RÄvaá¹‡a taste honey,
Both become faults.
Using scales to deceive people does not count as stealing, selling meat constitutes killing.
Sheep and rice both have life, eating rice does not constitute killing,
Sheep and rice should both be eaten, why eat rice
But not eat sheep?
One will never be reborn in the heavens, falling off cliffs or drowning in water,
It is said one will be reborn in the heavens.

Furthermore, I once heard that in a certain country, the royal lineage was about to be cut off. Like that sage king asking the bed-maker for everything.

Furthermore, it is heard that there was a king whose body suffered from illness, and the doctors in the country were all unable to cure him.

Having arrived in the heavens, it is like returning home and seeing various prosperous events. Only then does one give rise to a reverent mind towards the king and know that he is the one who repays kindness, the patron donor.

He then spoke a verse, saying:
When giving without seeing retribution, the mind has doubts and regrets,
Thinking it is in vain hard work, ultimately nothing is gained.
Having been reborn in the intermediate state, one only then sees the good appearance,

(88) Furthermore, it is heard that there were two women who both obtained mangos. One woman ate the fruit without keeping the seeds, while the other woman ate the fruit but kept the seeds.

You are the one called Gaubata, why did you say you were behind?
Gaubata said to the relatives:
The one called Gaubata is not me, but the one on the camel in the group.
The reason is this:
Because my relatives despised me and did not speak to me before, but when they heard I had wealth, they came to welcome me. For this reason, I am on the camel behind.
The relatives said:
What are you talking about? We don't understand your words!
Gaubata then replied:
When I was poor, you all spoke to me but did not respond. Now that you see I have many treasures, you set up offerings and come to welcome me. You come for the sake of the wealth, not for my body.
